parameters.source_text:
Case 14-7
A Kidney from a Mentally Impaired Brother:
The Case of Jerry and Tommy Strunk
Tommy Strunk, a married 28-year-old employee of the Penn State Railroad
and part-time student at the University of Cincinnati, suffered from chronic
glomerulonephritis. He was being kept alive by dialysis, which could not
be continued much longer. He was considered for a deceased donor trans-
plant, but the waiting times were typically too long. His entire family was
tested to see if they could become living donors, including his parents and
a number of relatives.
As a last resort, his 27-year-old brother Jerry was tested and was found
compatible. He, however, had Down syndrome and was a resident of the
Frankfort State Hospital and school, described as being a state institution for
the “feebleminded.” He had an intelligence quotient (IQ) of approximately 35,
a mental age of approximately six years. He also had a speech defect,
making it difficult to communicate with those not well acquainted with him.
Ava Strunk, the mother of Tommy and Jerry, petitioned the court to ap-
prove procurement from Tommy. Normally, parents are obligated to serve
the best interests of their children. While the procurement would surely be
in Tommy’s interest, it seemed contrary to Jerry’s. The argument was made
that the kidney transplant would be beneficial not only to Tommy but also
to Jerry, “because Jerry was greatly dependent upon Tommy, emotionally
and psychologically, and that his well-being would be jeopardized more
severely by the loss of his brother than by the removal of a kidney.” The
issue is whether the court should approve.®

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man has end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis. He has been on dialysis for years and is now developing complications that make long-term dialysis increasingly difficult. A deceased-donor transplant is unlikely in time. His only compatible living donor is his 27-year-old brother, who has Down syndrome, lives in a state residential program, and communicates in short phrases. He enjoys visits with the patient and becomes distressed when separated from family routines. Their mother is his legal guardian and requests donation, saying the brothers are closely bonded. The brother can assent in a limited way but does not grasp long-term surgical risks or what losing a kidney means. A donor advocate notes that donation surgery is usually safe but not risk-free and will permanently change his medical future. Hospital policy and state law allow either proceeding with guardian consent and donor advocate approval or declining donation.
data.choice_1: Proceed with living-donor nephrectomy using guardian consent and donor advocate oversight
data.choice_2: Decline living donation and continue dialysis while awaiting a deceased-donor offer

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language implying transplant is medically necessary or clearly superior. Edit 'A deceased-donor transplant is unlikely in time' to something like 'The wait for a deceased-donor kidney is expected to be long and uncertain.' Edit 'developing complications that make long-term dialysis increasingly difficult' to 'dialysis is becoming more burdensome and may lead to additional complications over time, but it remains a viable option.' Avoid framing Choice 2 as futile; add that continuing dialysis is clinically acceptable though burdensome.

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Add a concrete forcing mechanism and timeframe. Examples: 'The transplant team must decide this week whether to list the brother as a living donor because the surgical slot/insurance authorization expires' OR 'the patient’s dialysis access is failing and a new access procedure is scheduled, but the transplant committee requires a decision before proceeding' OR 'the donor evaluation is complete and the hospital requires an accept/decline decision at this visit to reserve an operating date.' Make the urgency realistic without implying clinical superiority.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or refocus details that don’t affect the decision and add a few missing decision-critical facts. Consider removing 'becomes distressed when separated from family routines' unless it directly affects perioperative care/support. Add: whether the brother can express a consistent preference over time (and can refuse), baseline medical fitness for nephrectomy, and what specific independent safeguards are available (e.g., ethics committee review, ability of donor advocate to veto). Keep communication limits and guardianship status.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify plausibility around surrogate consent for adult living kidney donation with intellectual disability. Add institutional process elements commonly required: formal capacity assessment documenting inability to provide informed consent; independent donor advocate with authority to halt donation; psychosocial evaluation; ethics committee review; confirmation that donation poses no unusual medical risk to the donor and that post-op follow-up/support is feasible in the residential program.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 risks feeling ethically/clinically indefensible because the donor cannot understand long-term risks, making the 'reasonable clinician disagreement' less credible. To restore symmetry, add facts that make proceeding more defensible while preserving ethical tension: the brother repeatedly and consistently expresses a desire to donate in his own words; he shows understanding of the immediate procedure and short-term discomfort even if not long-term implications; the guardian is not the recipient; an independent advocate/ethics committee can veto; and there is no coercion or benefit to the guardian. Also strengthen that Choice 2 is not clearly unacceptable (dialysis remains workable, though burdensome), so declining is not tantamount to abandoning care.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither option feels ethically pre-decided by incapacity or medical urgency. (1) Strengthen the donor-side case for proceeding: specify the brother consistently expresses (in his own way) a stable wish to help/donate, can describe the basic surgery and short-term recovery, and would have robust independent donor-advocate assessment with the ability to halt the process. (2) Strengthen the recipient-side case for declining: clarify dialysis remains feasible for now (though increasingly burdensome) and that a deceased-donor offer is possible within a plausible timeframe, albeit uncertain, so declining is not tantamount to immediate death. (3) Soften language that makes proceeding feel obviously wrong: replace 'does not grasp long-term surgical risks or what losing a kidney means' with a more ambiguous capacity description (e.g., understands some elements but not others), creating a gray zone rather than clear incapacity. (4) Avoid implying the only reason to proceed is desperation: remove/temper 'unlikely in time' and instead describe a meaningful but uncertain wait. These edits create defensible tradeoffs on both sides rather than an apparent default to refusing donation.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften framing that makes declining donation seem medically futile. For example, replace “A deceased-donor transplant is unlikely in time” with “The expected deceased-donor wait is prolonged and clinically uncertain,” and avoid implying dialysis failure is imminent unless essential. Consider adding one neutral sentence noting that continuing dialysis remains medically feasible but with ongoing burden/complications, so neither option is implicitly ‘the only viable’ path.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clinicalize psychosocial descriptors. Replace “becomes distressed when separated from family routines” with “has anxiety/behavioral dysregulation with disruption of routine.” Remove nonessential relational details unless directly tied to voluntariness/coercion assessment (e.g., keep bonding only insofar as it affects assent and potential undue influence).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten choices to a single action each without process qualifiers. Example: Choice 1: “Proceed with living-donor nephrectomy from the brother under surrogate consent.” Choice 2: “Do not accept him as a donor; continue dialysis and pursue deceased-donor listing.” Keep donor-advocate/policy details in the vignette only.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry that currently makes declining donation feel safer/ethically cleaner. Add concrete, weighty harms on the recipient side if donation is declined (e.g., progressive access failure, repeated infections/hospitalizations, inability to maintain employment/caregiving role, high likelihood of dying before an organ becomes available) without using numbers. Also add ethically relevant costs of proceeding (e.g., donor’s postoperative distress from disrupted routines, need for postoperative restraint/sedation, long-term follow-up burden placed on residential program). Rephrase “usually safe” to neutral language (“routine but with real risks”) and avoid implying policy/law endorsement; clarify that donor advocate is divided or that ethics consult is available but not determinative. Ensure both options carry comparable moral weight in the narrative tone.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a realistic third path exists: defer and pursue supported-decision-making/capacity optimization for the brother (speech therapy, repeated discussions), seek alternative donors (paired exchange), seek expanded-criteria deceased donor listing, or request court review/ethics committee. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives: state paired exchange is not available/declined by program, no other potential donors after evaluation, and the transplant center requires a decision within a short window because the recipient’s dialysis access is failing. Alternatively, redefine the binary as ‘petition court/ethics committee to authorize donation’ vs ‘do not pursue authorization and remain on dialysis’ if that matches local process.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The case leans on ‘policy and state law allow either’ but does not explain why professional standards don’t settle it. Add that existing guidance on living donation from adults with intellectual disability is non-uniform and emphasizes individualized assessment, and that the brother’s partial assent/limited understanding falls into a gray zone. Clarify there is no clear legal requirement for court authorization in this jurisdiction (or, if there is, incorporate it so neither option is illegal). If any standard would clearly require court review when the donor lacks capacity, adjust the vignette so court review is optional/ambiguous, or make the decision about whether to seek court authorization (not to proceed immediately).

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language implying transplant is medically necessary or clearly superior. Edit 'A deceased-donor transplant is unlikely in time' to something like 'The wait for a deceased-donor kidney is expected to be long and uncertain.' Edit 'developing complications that make long-term dialysis increasingly difficult' to 'dialysis is becoming more burdensome and may lead to additional complications over time, but it remains a viable option.' Avoid framing Choice 2 as futile; add that continuing dialysis is clinically acceptable though burdensome.
decision_forcing_context: Add a concrete forcing mechanism and timeframe. Examples: 'The transplant team must decide this week whether to list the brother as a living donor because the surgical slot/insurance authorization expires' OR 'the patient’s dialysis access is failing and a new access procedure is scheduled, but the transplant committee requires a decision before proceeding' OR 'the donor evaluation is complete and the hospital requires an accept/decline decision at this visit to reserve an operating date.' Make the urgency realistic without implying clinical superiority.
key_information: Trim or refocus details that don’t affect the decision and add a few missing decision-critical facts. Consider removing 'becomes distressed when separated from family routines' unless it directly affects perioperative care/support. Add: whether the brother can express a consistent preference over time (and can refuse), baseline medical fitness for nephrectomy, and what specific independent safeguards are available (e.g., ethics committee review, ability of donor advocate to veto). Keep communication limits and guardianship status.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify plausibility around surrogate consent for adult living kidney donation with intellectual disability. Add institutional process elements commonly required: formal capacity assessment documenting inability to provide informed consent; independent donor advocate with authority to halt donation; psychosocial evaluation; ethics committee review; confirmation that donation poses no unusual medical risk to the donor and that post-op follow-up/support is feasible in the residential program.
non_triviality: As written, Choice 1 risks feeling ethically/clinically indefensible because the donor cannot understand long-term risks, making the 'reasonable clinician disagreement' less credible. To restore symmetry, add facts that make proceeding more defensible while preserving ethical tension: the brother repeatedly and consistently expresses a desire to donate in his own words; he shows understanding of the immediate procedure and short-term discomfort even if not long-term implications; the guardian is not the recipient; an independent advocate/ethics committee can veto; and there is no coercion or benefit to the guardian. Also strengthen that Choice 2 is not clearly unacceptable (dialysis remains workable, though burdensome), so declining is not tantamount to abandoning care.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Rebalance the case so neither option feels ethically pre-decided by incapacity or medical urgency. (1) Strengthen the donor-side case for proceeding: specify the brother consistently expresses (in his own way) a stable wish to help/donate, can describe the basic surgery and short-term recovery, and would have robust independent donor-advocate assessment with the ability to halt the process. (2) Strengthen the recipient-side case for declining: clarify dialysis remains feasible for now (though increasingly burdensome) and that a deceased-donor offer is possible within a plausible timeframe, albeit uncertain, so declining is not tantamount to immediate death. (3) Soften language that makes proceeding feel obviously wrong: replace 'does not grasp long-term surgical risks or what losing a kidney means' with a more ambiguous capacity description (e.g., understands some elements but not others), creating a gray zone rather than clear incapacity. (4) Avoid implying the only reason to proceed is desperation: remove/temper 'unlikely in time' and instead describe a meaningful but uncertain wait. These edits create defensible tradeoffs on both sides rather than an apparent default to refusing donation.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or soften framing that makes declining donation seem medically futile. For example, replace “A deceased-donor transplant is unlikely in time” with “The expected deceased-donor wait is prolonged and clinically uncertain,” and avoid implying dialysis failure is imminent unless essential. Consider adding one neutral sentence noting that continuing dialysis remains medically feasible but with ongoing burden/complications, so neither option is implicitly ‘the only viable’ path.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clinicalize psychosocial descriptors. Replace “becomes distressed when separated from family routines” with “has anxiety/behavioral dysregulation with disruption of routine.” Remove nonessential relational details unless directly tied to voluntariness/coercion assessment (e.g., keep bonding only insofar as it affects assent and potential undue influence).
choice_brevity: Shorten choices to a single action each without process qualifiers. Example: Choice 1: “Proceed with living-donor nephrectomy from the brother under surrogate consent.” Choice 2: “Do not accept him as a donor; continue dialysis and pursue deceased-donor listing.” Keep donor-advocate/policy details in the vignette only.
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Reduce asymmetry that currently makes declining donation feel safer/ethically cleaner. Add concrete, weighty harms on the recipient side if donation is declined (e.g., progressive access failure, repeated infections/hospitalizations, inability to maintain employment/caregiving role, high likelihood of dying before an organ becomes available) without using numbers. Also add ethically relevant costs of proceeding (e.g., donor’s postoperative distress from disrupted routines, need for postoperative restraint/sedation, long-term follow-up burden placed on residential program). Rephrase “usually safe” to neutral language (“routine but with real risks”) and avoid implying policy/law endorsement; clarify that donor advocate is divided or that ethics consult is available but not determinative. Ensure both options carry comparable moral weight in the narrative tone.
exhaustive_binary_options: As written, a realistic third path exists: defer and pursue supported-decision-making/capacity optimization for the brother (speech therapy, repeated discussions), seek alternative donors (paired exchange), seek expanded-criteria deceased donor listing, or request court review/ethics committee. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives: state paired exchange is not available/declined by program, no other potential donors after evaluation, and the transplant center requires a decision within a short window because the recipient’s dialysis access is failing. Alternatively, redefine the binary as ‘petition court/ethics committee to authorize donation’ vs ‘do not pursue authorization and remain on dialysis’ if that matches local process.
no_guideline_override: The case leans on ‘policy and state law allow either’ but does not explain why professional standards don’t settle it. Add that existing guidance on living donation from adults with intellectual disability is non-uniform and emphasizes individualized assessment, and that the brother’s partial assent/limited understanding falls into a gray zone. Clarify there is no clear legal requirement for court authorization in this jurisdiction (or, if there is, incorporate it so neither option is illegal). If any standard would clearly require court review when the donor lacks capacity, adjust the vignette so court review is optional/ambiguous, or make the decision about whether to seek court authorization (not to proceed immediately).

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man has end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis. He has been on dialysis for years. Dialysis remains viable, but it is increasingly burdensome. His vascular access has required repeated procedures and he has had intermittent infections and hospitalizations. His nephrologist worries he may not be able to keep working if this continues. The expected wait for a deceased-donor kidney is long and uncertain. No other family or friends were medically eligible to donate, and his center cannot offer paired exchange for this blood type. His only compatible living donor is his 27-year-old brother with Down syndrome who lives in a state residential program. A capacity evaluation finds he can describe the surgery and short-term pain and has repeatedly said he wants to “give a kidney,” but he cannot reliably explain long-term risks or future health implications. Disruption of routine may require sedation or temporary restraints after surgery, and the residence must commit to lifelong follow-up. An independent donor advocate can veto donation, and the ethics service is available but divided. Hospital policy and state law permit either proceeding with guardian consent or declining donation. The transplant team must decide this week to keep the surgical slot and donor clearance valid.
data.choice_1: Accept the brother as a living donor and schedule nephrectomy with guardian consent
data.choice_2: Decline him as donor and continue dialysis while awaiting a deceased-donor kidney

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man has end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis. He has been on dialysis for years. Dialysis remains viable, but it is increasingly burdensome. His vascular access has required repeated procedures and he has had intermittent infections and hospitalizations. His nephrologist worries he may not be able to keep working if this continues. The expected wait for a deceased-donor kidney is long and uncertain. No other family or friends were medically eligible to donate, and his center cannot offer paired exchange for this blood type. His only compatible living donor is his 27-year-old brother with Down syndrome who lives in a state residential program. A capacity evaluation finds he can describe the surgery and short-term pain and has repeatedly said he wants to “give a kidney,” but he cannot reliably explain long-term risks or future health implications. Disruption of routine may require sedation or temporary restraints after surgery, and the residence must commit to lifelong follow-up. An independent donor advocate can veto donation, and the ethics service is available but divided. Hospital policy and state law permit either proceeding with guardian consent or declining donation. The transplant team must decide this week to keep the surgical slot and donor clearance valid.

choice_1.choice: Accept the brother as a living donor and schedule nephrectomy with guardian consent

choice_2.choice: Decline him as donor and continue dialysis while awaiting a deceased-donor kidney

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add an explicit statement about whether the brother is assenting/refusing at present (e.g., “he continues to affirm he wants to donate today” or “he becomes distressed and says he wants to stop”) to make the autonomy conflict unambiguous.

Add a clause explicitly framing beneficence as a tradeoff between the recipient’s expected survival/quality-of-life benefit from transplant and the brother-donor’s surgical + long-term health risks given limited understanding (e.g., “the team must weigh the recipient’s substantial expected benefit against the donor’s nontrivial perioperative and lifetime risks”).

Add a clause explicitly framing the dilemma as fairness/protection of a vulnerable donor vs giving the recipient equitable access to transplant (e.g., “the team worries accepting a cognitively disabled institutionalized donor could be exploitative and set an unfair precedent”).

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man has end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis. He has been on dialysis for years. Dialysis is still an option, but it is increasingly burdensome. His vascular access has required repeated procedures, and he has had intermittent infections and hospitalizations. The wait for a deceased-donor kidney is long and uncertain. No other family or friends are medically eligible to donate, and his center cannot offer paired exchange for this blood type. His only compatible living donor is his 27-year-old brother with Down syndrome who lives in a state residential program. A capacity evaluation finds he can describe the surgery and short-term pain. Today he again affirms he wants to donate. He cannot reliably explain long-term risks or future health implications. Disruption of routine may require sedation or temporary restraints after surgery, and the residence must commit to lifelong follow-up. The team must weigh the recipient’s substantial expected benefit against the donor’s nontrivial perioperative and lifetime risks. They also worry about protecting a vulnerable donor and setting a precedent that could be exploitative. Hospital policy and state law permit either proceeding with guardian consent or declining donation. The transplant team must decide this week to keep the surgical slot and donor clearance valid.

choice_1.choice: Accept the brother as a living donor and schedule nephrectomy with guardian consent

choice_2.choice: Decline him as donor and continue dialysis while awaiting a deceased-donor kidney

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man has end-stage kidney disease from chronic glomerulonephritis. He has been on dialysis for years. Dialysis is still an option, but it is increasingly burdensome. His vascular access has required repeated procedures, and he has had intermittent infections and hospitalizations. The wait for a deceased-donor kidney is long and uncertain. No other family or friends are medically eligible to donate, and his center cannot offer paired exchange for this blood type. His only compatible living donor is his 27-year-old brother with Down syndrome who lives in a state residential program. A capacity evaluation finds he can describe the surgery and short-term pain. Today he again affirms he wants to donate. He cannot reliably explain long-term risks or future health implications. Disruption of routine may require sedation or temporary restraints after surgery, and the residence must commit to lifelong follow-up. The team must weigh the recipient’s substantial expected benefit against the donor’s nontrivial perioperative and lifetime risks. They also worry about protecting a vulnerable donor and setting a precedent that could be exploitative. Hospital policy and state law permit either proceeding with guardian consent or declining donation. The transplant team must decide this week to keep the surgical slot and donor clearance valid.

choice_1.choice: Accept the brother as a living donor and schedule nephrectomy with guardian consent

choice_2.choice: Decline him as donor and continue dialysis while awaiting a deceased-donor kidney
